item.title: M. add a quote by Thomas Edison
item.description: "We are like tenant farmers chopping down the fence around our house for fuel when we should be using Nature’s inexhaustible sources of energy--sun, wind and tide. I’d put my money on the sun and solar energy. What a source of power! I hope we don’t have to wait until oil and coal run out before we tackle that." -- Thomas Edison

item.title: M. add a quote by Søren Kierkegaard
item.description: "No woman in maternity confinement can have stranger and more impatient wishes than I have." -- Søren Kierkegaard

item.title: M. add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: M. add a quote by Douglas Adams
item.description: "I love deadlines. I love the whooshing noise they make as they go by." -- Douglas Adams

item.title: M. add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "Hunger not to have, but to be" -- John Dewey

item.title: M. add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "We only think when confronted with a problem." -- John Dewey

item.title: M. add a quote by Maurice Merleau-Ponty
item.description: "The world is... the natural setting of, and field for, all my thoughts and all my explicit perceptions. Truth does not inhabit only the inner man, or more accurately, there is no inner man, man is in the world, and only in the world does he know himself. " -- Maurice Merleau-Ponty

item.title: M. add a quote by William James
item.description: "A great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices." -- William James

item.title: M. add a quote by William James
M. add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "For in spite of itself any movement that thinks and acts in terms of an ‘ism becomes so involved in reaction against other ‘isms that it is unwittingly controlled by them. For it then forms its principles by reaction against them instead of by a comprehensive, constructive survey of actual needs, problems, and possibilities." -- John Dewey

item.title: M. add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "The path of least resistance and least trouble is a mental rut already made. It requires troublesome work to undertake the alteration of old beliefs. " -- John Dewey

item.title: M. add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "Conflict is the gadfly of thought. It stirs us to observation and memory. It instigates invention. It shocks us out of sheep-like passivity, and sets us at noting and contriving…conflict is a sine qua non of reflection and ingenuity." -- John Dewey
